content.body: morning

I was looking at a website's source after the owner said that it's using html5 and noticed a lot of tags inside an <article> tag. Lik <header> div's some p's and footer. Is that a correct use of the tag?
Website is http://ryanmerrill.net/
Looks legit: http://validator.nu/?doc=http://ryanmerrill.net/
I think the validator is a bit too forgiving :P
I checked it there before coming here, but would you agree that the article tag isn't so appropriate there?
Maybe a section would of been better
the <article> seems fine
the <hgroup>s at the top are a little more dubious
should probably just be one of them or something
not really clear what the right outline would be
hm, I see
dammit
MikeSmith: ?
othermaciej: ah, nothing specific, just a general curse.. several things not working as expected
e.g., I'm trying the Check for Updates option in Opera.. I select it and nothing happens
and my XChat not working like it should
othermaciej: btw, I tried Colloquy and really liked it, but it didn't work as expected with this "tircd" thing that I use for twitter
MikeSmith: what's tircd?
IRC-to-twitter gateway?
yeah
oh hey MikeSmith
boblet: hey man
you been trying to ping me for a while
heh—wondering if I need to book a park bench for next Wednesday or not :)
yeah, sure, definitely
thanks man (as always)
also did you get any info about the speech? just an hour on whatever, huh?
yeah, I think so
hope my Japanese is in working order that day
mine will be in its usual order, namely bad
hehe. I figure lots of code examples np
I will do what I can but will probably end up being lazy and falling back to English and kataka-izing prolificly
as far as my part, I'm just going to do a walk-through of the validator.nu sources and demo
btw, I think Hatano-san will be making a visit to Osaka some time soon
to do a presentation that we helped line up for him
boblet: hey, I didn't tell you but Isshiki-san and Ashimura-san and I were in Osaka a couple weeks ago
I didn't call you because it was a whirlwind visit
MikeSmith: I think Hatano-san is here for next week right? Hopefully gonna catch up in the weekend
heh, np. what’s with all the activity down here? *nothing* happens here :/
dunno when he's going, didn't realize it was that soon
boblet: visiting friends at Panasonic
Kyoto if I’m not getting confused
aah, nice
we arrived at lunchtime then had a couple meetings and then left pretty early because we had something else we had to go to the next day in Tokyo
yikes. you weren’t kidding
btw, thanks for that smoked meat. That stuff is amazing. ate it with some australian red wine, because I was hungry and had neither a razor nor a bottle of Laphroig close at hand
good stuff. yeah Aussie red works well—will bring some up for next month…
wishes <address> could be used inline (want to add copyright info to same sentence)
has no idea what to do with ian's idea of uploading directories
hi, i was wondering if someone had a general idea of the status of web fonts today?
i mean, håkon lie made a stir around 2007/2008, and i haven't heard much about it since
what's generally supported these days? tt? eot? plain opentype? woff?
sorry for not having a very specific question :p just wondered if you have any opinions
murr4y: I think the css3.info site might have some details
murr4y: http://www.css3.info/?s=font
nice, thank you
ooh, larry made a Formal Objection to publishing the drafts, quelle surprise
murr4y: for syntax check http://paulirish.com/2009/bulletproof-font-face-implementation-syntax/
annevk, I don't see Larry's objection anywhere on public-html
annevk: where?
see the minutes of the telcon
<masinter> do I need to repeat objections?
paulc: the co-chairs are aware of the formal objection
rubys: it would be helpful to repeat the objection
paulc: it would be helpful to people who aren't reading w3-archive email
so I guess his objection was originally sent to w3c-archive
oh. I didn't know you are allowed to make FOs in secret
The section "On Standards" in http://blogs.adobe.com/jnack/2010/01/sympathy_for_the_devil.html is insightful
for those with access, this is the only mention of an objection that I can find from Larry http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/w3c-archive/2010Feb/0108.html
maybe I missed the actual objection elsewhere, since that talks about it in past tense
it'd be awesome if adobe selled authoring tools for html5
i hope they'll do it
hsivonen, I guess it shows that the W3C approach might not really work
zcorpan__, I expect them to update Dreamweaver with HTML5 support
Lachy: i mean the tools they currently have to produce flash content
Why would anyone object to publishing drafts? :S
has anyone else noticed how larry's e-mails get narrower and narrower the longer they get?
i wonder what causes that
it messes with my head anytime i actually read all the way through his long e-mails
custom line breaks?
Hixie: as in a funnel shape?
asmodai: yeah, though left-aligned
clearly, if you pull an email to make it longer, it has to get narrower
wedge shaped
mmm, are the emails angry in tone? Anger might explain rational thoughts short circuiting causing use of smaller sentences or so.
Hixie, fyi, redirects are a mess
asmodai: not especially
which begs the question, what isn't?
Hixie: Mmm, interesting then.
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Jan/0539.html is an example of the wedge
though it's more a step than a wedge
Wonder if he hits enter manually.
no response to my comment on http://blogs.adobe.com/jd/2010/02/adobe_authoring_for_html5.html :-(
I'm not sure what to think of Adobe nowadays to be honest.
I dislike Flash with a passion in some areas and can understand its use in some others.
Hixie: never noticed the wedge before - that's weird
it's really noticable in http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/w3c-archive/2010Feb/0100.html
also http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/w3c-archive/2010Feb/0079.html
i love how http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/w3c-archive/2010Feb/0106.html talks about how transparency is important
lolz
so cross-document messaging is without a W3C home for now?
didn't realize that was nuked from orbit too at the W3C
Hixie, sorry that's a password protected link... :?
surely not, the author clearly indicates that transparency is important
i hope all the w3c member archives eventually get archived in public, for future historians to marvel over
reads some of the webapps rechartering thread yesterday ... not so fun reading
Someone should archive it all now, and post it on Wikileaks in 20 years once nobody cares that much about keeping it private any more
something like that seems reasonable
hixie could donate his inbox too
Hixie, http://dev.w3.org/html5/postmsg/#idl is empty?
Hixie, also, could you rename the draft to Web Messaging as was suggested by othermaciej? then I can simply reference it as such from html5-diff
annevk: what got nuked from the orbit and how? did one of the split out part not get adopted by webapps?
pretty much
though maybe after june
yay for time to market
blogs
annevk: done
hsivonen: that spec is probably one of the most widely implement features of HTML5 (at least as far as actually new features go)
othermaciej: fortunately implementations don't wait until CR
so it doesn't actually matter
however WebApps is likely to complete rechartering within a few months at which point it can be published as FPWD
was anything else split out that I didn't notice?
Am I the only one to think "quantum particle theory" when reading the "Message Channels" section of the HTML5 Messaging document...
heh
the spec even uses the term "entangled"
it's not a coincidence :-)
That's a comfort. Means I haven't become too geeky yet.
i did physics at university
Are there any plans to extend message channels between different hosts (by which I mean hosting environment/browser) or is it strictly in-browser currently?
annevk: I think microdata, microdata vocabularies, canvas 2d context, and postMessage/MessageChannel are the only drafts spun off since our last publication
i occasionally like to give hat tips to my old subject :-)
oh right, microdata vocabularies
is that the three separate drafts?
who's publishing those?
apart from the WHATWG, of course
vocabs are gone altogether currently in w3c space
there's still editor drafts in cvs
but okay
it's not being updated
k
i'm adding "Specific microdata vocabularies are gone altogether in the W3C draft
of HTML5 and are not published as a separate draft. The WHATWG draft of
HTML5 still includes them."
Hixie: can you remind me of your POST test case?
Hixie: the one that demonstrates how to do a POST without the user's permission and without using scripting?
it's in this directory: http://damowmow.com/playground/demos/http/002/
Hixie: thanks
one of my favorite test cases ever :-)
yeah i kinda like that one too
that's sort of hard to protect against, no?
nah, not really
same-origin, just avoid doing it
cross-origin, use Origin or other CSRF protections
yes, in terms of protecting the server
also delivering some hash to the user in a hidden form field
I was more concerned with the "let's hide from the user that we're doing a post"
and that's a harder problem to protect against
not clear that it's a problem
Hixie: it's a problem only to the extent that web sites are broken
how do you mean?
(which is to say, they are, but I don't think we can fix problems that lie between a developer's chair and keyboard)
same-origin, the server can do whatever it wants anyway, without the client even being involved
so it's not clear to me why it matters whether you're doing a GET or a POST
there are advantages to do with UI that give good reasons to do the "right" one
but i don't see any particular threat from being able to "trick" the user into doing a same-origin post with the user's knowledge
if there was, the whole web would have broken down long ago :-)
given that you can script a .post(), etc
er, a .submit(), not a .post()
What makes you think the web hasn't broken down long ago? :-)
if this is broken, i'd love to see it working!
If this is working, I'd hate to see it broken :-p
"broken" would be like the web in the 80s
Hixie: the web didn't exist in the 80's (well... 89, but that's barely the 80's)
although I guess not-existing is a form of broken :)
that's what i meant, yeah :-)
and wow, I need to start checking time-stamps and not reviving hours old arguments :)
hides
gsnedders: fair point :)
The English language has been broken for decades...
is blatantly too much of a QA to allow such bugs
Hixie: That would be better still

remembers at joint HTML-WG/TAG meeting in '08 timbl making some comment about work on HTML going back 18.5 years, and just commenting in IRC: "/me feels like a n00b, again", causing several people in the meeting to laugh
i wonder if maybe we should just punt on PUT and DELETE methods
for form submission
I've learned that parser performance isn't parsing but painting
it's not clear that they're really useful given XHR
hsivonen: did you cause too many incremental updates?
othermaciej: yes.
also, it's annoying that Mac and Vista have so different perf characteristics than XP&Linux
Hixie: Wouldn't the same line of reasoning apply to GET and POST then?
i understand the use cases for GET and POST from a form's perspective
PUT and DELETE are a bit less obvious
when was the last time you deleted something that had a URL?
It stems from the church of REST
Isn't that whole GET/POST/PUT/DELETE at least directly mappable to CRUD?
yeah, i guess it depends how much you buy into the whole REST thing
Hixie: looking for the wrath of HTTP fans again?
hsivonen: no, i'm trying to work out how to deal with actual issues raised
if you make it same-origin only (and not allowed to follow cross-origin redirects) then it should be safe
To be fair I never used PUT/DELETE in forms at all since, err, they don't work :-)
I don't know whether it would actually be useful
I do POST to /delete
Well, the theory being that if you would PUT to, e.g. a post reply on a forum, there would be no risk of double posts since you'd overwrite the last one

I still find the names of PUT and POST confusing. My mind is also nagging me about missing implementations of DELETE in some webservers or so since it is hardly used. Good chance I'm confusing it with something else though.
now I am curious how control values affect the request for a PUT or DELETE form
It would be useful if people doing forms subscribe to REST. Otherwise, no, not really. So to me that's the question to ask.
it looks like per HTML5, method=DELETE ignores the contents of form controls and just makes a DELETE method request to the action URI
that would make DELETE as a form action kind of useless
hmm, IETF fail
for PUT, the form contents are encoded into the body, but it seems unlikely that you'd want to upload a resource using any of the three formats...
http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5646 says it is bcp47 but http://tools.ietf.org/html/bcp47 says it is http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4647 which is not obsoleted by the first URL...
yay for BCP stability
Well, for DELETE I would assume if there were form contents (such as a list of items to delete) you could encode it in the URL like for GET.
yeah, but HTML5 does not say to do that, and it's not clear that would be a good behavior anyway
because then you could only delete resources that have a query in their URI
yeah it'd make no sense to do that
I don't see why? Isn't the query ignored if the remote side isn't interested in it?
DELETE would only make sense in the context of a <button> with a formaction="" attribute
PUT doesn't really make any sense at all
both were mostly added for parity wiht xforms back in the day
lots of people seemed to want them
PUT would make sense if you could upload the contents of a file (from <input type=file>) without any other junk prepended or appended
or upload the contents of a text field or contentEditable area
PUT doesn't literally mean what the form PUTS to the resource is the end result, though?
uploading urlencoded or multipart form data does not seem very useful
meledin: that's what http PUT is supposed to mean
(roughly)
My understanding is it just means it overwrites the previous data and it's deterministic in its behaviour
how the data is encoded has no relevance to PUT afaict
for PUT wouldn't you normally want to submit something in a form that could make sense to serve as a resource?
that's certainly how atompub uses it
Creating a thread on a forum, for example? PUT-ing the same form several times (e.g. reload/back/forward) doesn't create multiple threads
meledin: Why doesn't it?
How does the HTTP method make any difference to that, in particular?
othermaciej, but the server could take the data out of the multipart and use it as resource, no?
Seems like you could do it with POST if you just add some unique form identifier each time you generate the editing form
which is the same as you'd have to do with PUT except there you'd put the unique ID in the URL to make it point at a new resource, I guess
annevk: could in theory - but that doesn't seem to be the intent of PUT as I understand it
annevk: for example it seems like you might want to be able to use PUT to talk to an atompub service, but PUT from a form HTML5-style would make that impossible
I do think PUT could make sense if you could identify a single control and PUT its value
"Unless otherwise specified for a particular entity-header, the entity-headers in the PUT request SHOULD be applied to the resource created or modified by the PUT." -- othermaciej seems right.
Don't see any mention of "servers can/should ignore content-type on PUT".
entity-header != entity body
but I don't really care either way :)
maybe not allowing them is better because they have this awkward same-origin restriction

Philip`: Basically, you're right. The end result is the same. In the PUT case, though, the end result is forced as part of the programming model, while in the POST case the programmer has to think. Being a dumb monkey, I like not thinking.
Seems like the actual implementation requires the same amount of thinking in either case
The conceptual model of resources and identifiers might make the solution easier to discover, though
For you and me? Yeah. For someone who hasn't encountered this particular issue before? ... what you said in fancier words.
but you can use that conceptual model regardless of the implementation details
and the HTML spec/language is not an effective way to teach people that model
I've no strong opinions on the last point. I just jumped in as devil's advocate on the reasoning "it's useless because it can be done with XHR"
doesn't have strong opinions on any points, because he doesn't actually care about any of it
Apparently enough to correct someone who's wrong on the Internet ;-)
oh it's not useless because it can be done with XHR
it's useless in general, and, because it can be done with XHR, the use cases that remain are already possible anyway.
that would be a better way to put it.
changes to the design could potentially make it useful, but it's not clear if they are worthwhile, given that you can do it with XHR
at least, now that XHR can upload a file
I now and then think we should value scriptless solutions a bit more, but maybe that's old school
I think scriptless solutions for common use cases are valuable
Scriptless is awesome, especially for stuff end-users never need to see
Because it is highly improbable it can go wrong
I'm not sure what distinction you are making

Then take it that it's worthless I guess :-) I just meant it's useful (to me) to make admin views, and debug views and such in plain HTML without JS or even CSS because it's trivial (to me). Add JS to the equation and now I have to debug
doubts the wisdom of making isindex a parser macro
isn't it like that in other browsers?
e.g. Opera
and IE too I believe
there's so little isindex compat that we could do the sane thing
Would anyone notice if we coated isindex in concrete and dumped it in the harbour in the middle of the night?
sane being dropping it altogether?
in Opera, the macro is rooted in an isindex element
in WebKit, the text field in the macro is an element with the name isindex
well, I'll remove the isindex tests from the DOM Level 2 HTML test suite and see if I can get r+
isindex being a macro has caused me disproportionate grief compared to its usefulness
don't you need to implement the special processing semantics for isindex form submission?
annevk: Yes! there's more grief ahead of me before the parser can be shipped!
gestures angrily in the general direction of isindex
<keygen> might be tricky too
given how that's implemented in Gecko
sane being parsing it like a proper void element
somewhat unfortunate how a disproportionate amount of time goes to bogus features of the past
if people dropped support for isindex, who would break?
sent email. I wasn't particularly eloquent, because I'm pretty annoyed with isindex right now
Seriously do we have any examples of actual sites that break due to <isindex> being broken?
s/broken/missing/
I'm even more angered when I consider the Concorde effect and how much effort I've already put into isindex
http://likelylotusblue.com/cgi-bin/webglimpse/
You'd break that kind of thing if <isindex> wasn't supported at all
Oops, that one's broken anyway
http://likelylotusblue.com/cgi-bin/webglimpse/home/llbadmin/likelylotusblue-www
That's slightly less broken but still broken
not very convincing examples :)
http://costard.lbl.gov/cgi-bin/man/man2html - there's one
It works if you enter something like "cat"
sweet
fails to find any other examples that actually work
ooh, am I being tentatively accused of FUD on public-html?
I wonder how depressing it would be to find the last useful email on that list
oh, there was exactly 1 non-process related email today
How did that get through?
Maybe the process needs to be improved to prevent that from happening
and yesterday around 3 or 4
it's sad, though for sure the Process moguls can declare victory for now
I have GMail use nearly identical colors for whatwg, htmlwg, and webapps list emails, so I can't tell which is which without specifically looking for it.
also, http://twitter.com/shelleypowers/status/8296745940 didn't last very long
And you are surprised why?
was that in reply to TabAtkins?
someone should raise a objection about the violation of process that allowed that non-process related e-mail to get through.
you might upset the Process moguls
Hixie: Well, your post made it to the front of reddit ;)
oh wait, second page
it's really no wonder people prefer the WHATWG list if you study the numbers a bit
link to the reddit entry?
Heh, just challenged Lawson to a drink-off.
Now just have to find an excuse to be in the same place as him.
TabAtkins, it seems like a drink-off is a reasonable excuse.
Tell my wife that.  ^_^
ok, is she in IRC?
No.
annevk: http://www.reddit.com/r/web_design/comments/b19ob/adobe_now_holding_up_publication_of_the_html5/
well, then pass on my message for me :-)
I will direct you to her soonest.  ^_^
anyone happen to have a xbl binding for details/summary, properly styled, that works with xbl2.js google code?
is not holding his breath
Nope.

Maybe the idea is to split the HTML5 language into as many tiny pieces as possible, and then you can block every one of the pieces except the tiny core that still has the name "HTML5" attached to it, and then you can claim you're not blocking HTML5
tks anyway....(wasn't *even* gonna include "accessible" in that question)
can't think of any reasonable and common meaning of "HTML5" by which the 2D canvas context is not part of HTML5
othermaciej, you didn't finish your sentence on public-webapps
othermaciej, also, that test seems very pointless to optimize for
annevk: apparently Mozilla and Microsoft both thought it was sufficiently common to do getElementsByTagName in a loop that they optimized for it years before this test existed
(in fact, with caching it's not even that much of a perf hit to do it in a loop)
exposing the gc seems very wrong
also you can optimize by creating small js objects
and doing other tricks
the overhead is in doing a GC allocation at all
there is no trick you can use to get the speed back
http://www.hotelgoal.com/city/vn/hotel-in-bai-chay.htm
for(i=0; i< document.getElementById(frm).getElementsByTagName('SELECT').length; i++){
if(document.getElementById(frm).getElementsByTagName('SELECT')[i].value==0){
Is that what the optimisation is for?
Philip`: yes
Philip`: there's only 4 select elements in that page afaict so the effect in this case would be small
It looks a very common pattern
http://www.esiweb.org/index.php?lang=fr&id=280&portrait_ID=66&function=print
while (document.getElementsByTagName("span")[i] != null) {
if (document.getElementsByTagName("span")[i].className
othermaciej, you don't think the gc issue is a problem?
annevk: I dont think setting custom properties on NodeLists is at all common, so I don't think it's an issue in practice, even though it is theoretically nondeterministic behavior
we could forbid custom properties on nodelists

annevk: if we really wanted to avoid it, we could require returning the same object, which to the level of observational equivalence would require caching it so long as it is live, or if it has ever had a custom property set
but I don't think that is worth the effort
or pin objects
yeah
Lots seem to be looping over 'a' and 'img', so I imagine there's going to be quite a few of those
Philip`: thanks for finding actual examples
See also http://google.com/codesearch?q=getElementsByTagName%5C%28%5B%5E%29%5D%2B%5C%29%5C%5B%5Ba-zA-Z%5D
it seems somewhat dangerous to me
Philip`: clever search regexp
time for a beer
there is probably a small risk of depending on nondeterministic behavior in the unlikely case someone really does set custom properties
Hi, have i came to the right place to ask about semantic mark up involving html 5?
Yeah, basically
do you get any benefit from using input=search i'm aware of the other new fields which offer validation
you get a neat little x button to clear the field (in chrome/safari)
ahhh ok thank you, these new ui widgets are much better for making web apps
Hixie, Hi.
openstandards, http://diveintohtml5.org/forms.html
That mentions how most browsers implement the various input types.
type="search" mainly just looks more like a native search box on Macs.
But it's conceivable that browsers will treat it cleverly in other ways in the future, so why not.
and these are proposals for others, but not implemented quite yet http://docs.google.com/View?id=dch3zh37_0cf8kc8c4
(Actually, it looks wrong on Chrome on Windows/Linux, IMO: http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=21560 )
paul_irish, well, those are proposals for WebKit, yeah.
Opera and iPhone already implement some of that.
aye
AryehGregor, i've been playing about with the html 5 spec for sometime opera seems to be leading the way
openstandards, in some parts yes, some parts no.
with webforms definitely
For instance, it's only just getting localStorage support in 10.50, IIRC.
But yeah, it's had a pretty complete Web Forms implementation for a long time now, it's neat.
i do like the datepicker function thats been added to the spec, thats extremely neat
i haven't seen much info on <menu> yet hows that treated?
aroben, thank you for that rather interesting article never knew the iphone's browser was that good
openstandards: I think you might have the wrong person
grrrrr sorry i never tabbed enough
tab complete very useful function when used correctly
With the html5lib serialiser, how can I make it not output doctypes?
tail -n +2
In the token serialiser loop: if text != '<!DOCTYPE html>'
That works well enough for me
w3c-archive is accessible to who?  Not people who are just HTMLWG Invited Experts, right?
No
Hurrah.
Members only, I think
What's it used for?
Well, I'm a "member" of the HTMLWG, just I only have public access, I think.  Or something.
For hiding things from mere invited experts, I guess
but I don't know since I can't see it
I can't even find a public list description.
AryehGregor: But you're not a Member
Oh, maybe I'm a Participant but not a Member?  http://www.w3.org/2000/09/dbwg/details?group=40318&public=1
It says "(public)" next to my name, I guess that means I don't get to see the cool secret stuff.
I think Members are only employees of http://www.w3.org/Consortium/Member/List
For some people it says "(public) Invited expert", and for some it says "W3C Invited Experts".
Like Tantek is a W3C Invited Expert.
Maybe I should bug someone to get Wikimedia joining the W3C and make me their representative.
Doesn't seem worth it.  I guess I'll have to if I become a full-time employee at any point, though.
Would that be a good use of $8000 of Wikimedia's money?
Probably, it has "advancing open standards" as part of its mission.

http://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Values "We believe that this mission requires thriving open formats and open standards on the web to allow the creation of content not subject to restrictions on creation, use, and reuse."
Would W3C membership help advance open standards?
Heh.
AryehGregor: if you get invited as an Invited Expert to any group but HTML WG, you'd probably become a real Invited Expert
more than spending the money/resources on other things
othermaciej, because in most groups, Invited Experts are actually invited experts?  :)
and contributing from a non-Member perspective
I dunno, that's not my decision.
I think that if I get employed by them, though, they have to become a member if I'm to remain part of the HTMLWG, or something?
AryehGregor: in most groups, yeah, you have to be actually invited
the $8k fee for nonprofits seems kinda steep
othermaciej, that it does
Wikimedia has about $8.6m in revenue for FY2008, so I guess they'd be able to afford it if necessary.  Dunno.
They plan to make $10.6m in 2009-10.

AryehGregor: I don't believe they do - you can be an Invited Expert as long as your employer is not a Member, though it seems they don't like IE status being used as a way to circumvent membership fees
s/they do/they do have to become a member/
Philip`, when I signed up, I was asked if my employer had anything to do with the web, or something like that.
I don't know how strict they are about nonprofits
That's a point, maybe they'd be nice.  Dunno.
I'd expect that if you're contributing as an individual then that's okay
I'll deal with that when I come to it.
rather than contributing as effectively an official representative of your employer
See, this is what WF2 is good for: http://img.thedailywtf.com/images/201002/errord/linkedinwtf.png
Wikimedia being a W3C Member would probably be a good thing for marginally improving the quality of AC decisions
othermaciej, yeah, I was thinking it would be a good thing to have more members whose interests actually lie with a free web.
I was thinking from the POV of caring about open source issues, and also just a large content publisher that cares about advancing the web platform
Right.
I wonder if the list at <http://www.w3.org/Consortium/Member/List> is actually current
You'd think $7,900 would be enough to pay someone to update the list.
I thought I'd heard that Yahoo! is not a member any more
That would be pretty interesting.
It is sad though that there aren't more large content publishers represented (and ideally active in the HTML WG)
it would be nice to hear direct from e.g. Facebook or Twitter or Amazon what they'd like to see
Yeah, kind of funny that none of them are part of the W3C.
